analyzeResult.content:
asbestas
Fortunately, the tissue derangement at the quid site usually progresses slowly through stages of inflammation, Jonkoplakia, verrucous alterations, and frank malignancy over a period of: 10 to-40 years. Signs of any of these pre- malignant changes are a warning either to switch chewing gum or to fight cancer.
From a practical standpoint, elderly patients who have no evidence of local irritation at the quid site need only worry about the systemic effects of nicotine on the cardio- vascular system. There are no controlled studies of these dangers, and they are probably less than the hazards of switching to burning tobacco and the risk of fire.
Despite the painted bull on the barns, snuff is a hazard to health.
GEORGE F. MOORZ, MD Roswell Park Memorial Institute Buffalo Parsing Lurking
"Cigarette Smoke-Filled Room:" A Hazard to Nonsmokers and Children
2 Is there evidence to support recent claims that a nonsmoker with an all day, exposure to a smoke-filled room inhales as much smoke as though he himself had smoked a pack of cigarettes?"
STEPHEN BARRETT, MD! Allentown, Pa
A Your concern about the hazard of exposure to a smoke-filled room. is supported by studies done by Harmsen and Effenberger (Arch Hyg Bakteriol 141:383- 400; 1957): They demonstrated that smoking several ciga- rettes in a closed. room soon makes the concentration of nicotine and dust particles so high that the nonsmoker in- hales as much harmful tobacco by-products as a smoker in- hales from four or five cigarettes.
Skasselatti-Sforzolini reported (Medical Tribune, Dec:4, 1967) that smoke from an idling cigarette contains almost twice the tar and nicotine: of smoke inhaled while puffing. on a cigarette. On the average, smoke inhaled while: puff- ing on a cigarette contains 11.8 mg of tar and 0.8 mg of nicotine, as compared to 22.1 mg of tar and 1.4 mg of nico- tine frem idling smoke. Thus, smoke from an idling ciga- rotte may be twice as toxic as smoke: inhaled by the smoker. Although the concentration of harmful. sub- stances inhaled by the nonsmoker is less than the concen- tration inhaled by the smoker, the nonsmoker's exposure: will be for a greater period of time. Scasselatti-Sforzolinii indicated that smoking in an airplane "will obviously con- stitute something of a menace to a nonsmoking passen- ger:" It seems obvious that in the confines of an airplane, where a nonsmoker may be required to sit next to one or between two smokers, and where the alr circulation is typ- ically poor, the nonsmoker will be subjected to a signifi- cant health hazard from a smoker.
An editorial some years ago (Science 158:1527; 1967) con- cerned the pollution of air by cigarette smoke. In a poorly ventilated, smoke-filled room, concentrations of carbon monoxide can easily reach several hundred parts per mil- lion, thus exposing present smokers and nonsmokers to a toxic hazard. Two other components of cigarette smoke are nitrogen dioxide and hydrogen cyanide. The former is an acutely irritating gas and occurs in cigarette smoke in concentrations-liil times.that considered dangerous on ex- tended exposure.
2024955880
Questions and Answers
Cocarcinogenic Effect of Smoking and Asbestos Exposure
Q Inithe July 24, 1972, issue of THE JOURNAL a question appeared about compensability for lung cancer developing in an as- bestos worker who had'smoked a pack of cigarettes every day. for 30. years: The consultant who answered the question said that' he did: not Know of any such cases coming to litigation. He also stated he was unaware of any firm conclusions having been derived from studies aimed at determining whether or not there is a high inci. dence of cancer in smokers exposed to asbestos. I have been under the impression that asbestos workers who smoke are at a distinct risk with respect to lung cancer, more so than asbestos workers who. do not smoke. Can you tell me whether my, assumption is correct? MD, Missouri
A Information, concerning the increased risk of lung cancer among asbestos workers has been pub- lished." These data indicate that asbestos workers who smoke cigarettes have approximately eight times the risk. of death from lung cancer that other smokers of the same age have, who do not work with asbestos.
E: C. Hammond, ScD, and I will shortly publish the re+ sults of another study bearing on this question. We have followed up 9,590 asbestos-insulation workers from Jan 1, 1967, through Dec 31, 1971; each of these individuals had a history of cigarette smoking. We have calculated expected deaths and have compared them with those observed dur- ing the period in question. While 25 deaths from lung can- cer were expected, 134 occurred. There seems to be little doubt, then, that exposure to asbestos significantly in- creases the risk of lung cancer among cigarette smokers. I am aware, too, of a number of cases, adjudicated in favor of the plaintiff, that involved lung cancer associated with asbestos exposure in cigarette-smoking asbestos workers. tavgsc J. Seuskorr, MD Mount Sinai Schuel of Medicine New York
1. Seliko&T 10, Hammond'EC. Churg J: Asbestos exposure, smoking. and neoplasia. JAMA 204:106-112, 1968.
Hazard of Snuff
Is dipping snuff hazardous? Should it be discouraged in healthy elderly people? MD. Maryland
A There is no doubt that snuff and chewing tobac- co are carcinogenic. Chronic exposures of the nasal passages, mouth (J Am Geriatr Soc 1:497, 1953; Cancer 15:246, 1962), and even the ear canal (N. Engl J Med 262:819: 1960) to tobacco have induced cancer. Fortunately, snuff is no longer used to quiet babies, but retains some popularity among men and women in occupations where smoking is prohibited. Even the traditional bulging check of the baseball player now contains chewing gum, but not before many of the idols of yesteryear died of malignant neoplasms of the oral cavity.
The answers here published have been prepared hy competent wocheitiis. They do" sot. however, regevwent the opinions of any medical or otb-nonganizatin -uh-se kyovaly ically so viated in the reply. Anoty mons cumounirallonsentet beansonel Inery leti ter must contain the writer's name and address, but these will be emittediun ceptieit. Alt inquiries ruevive a direct mail reply ...
Questions and Answers
JAMA, Jan 15, 1973 . Val 223, No 3

Fortunately, the tissue derangement at the quid site
usually progresses slowly through stages of inflammation,
Jonkoplakia, verrucous alterations, and frank malignancy
over a period of: 10 to-40 years. Signs of any of these pre-
malignant changes are a warning either to switch
chewing gum or to fight cancer.
From a practical standpoint, elderly patients who have
no evidence of local irritation at the quid site need only
worry about the systemic effects of nicotine on the cardio-
vascular system. There are no controlled studies of these
dangers, and they are probably less than the hazards of
switching to burning tobacco and the risk of fire.
Despite the painted bull on the barns, snuff is a hazard
to health.
GEORGE F. MOORZ, MD
Roswell Park Memorial Institute
Buffalo

"Cigarette Smoke-Filled Room:"
A Hazard to Nonsmokers and Children
Is there evidence to support recent claims that a nonsmoker
with an all day, exposure to a smoke-filled room inhales as
much smoke as though he himself had smoked a pack of cigarettes?"
STEPHEN BARRETT, MD!
Allentown, Pa
A
Your concern about the hazard of exposure to a
smoke-filled room. is supported by studies done by
Harmsen and Effenberger (Arch Hyg Bakteriol 141:383-
400; 1957): They demonstrated that smoking several ciga-
rettes in a closed. room soon makes the concentration of
nicotine and dust particles so high that the nonsmoker in-
hales as much harmful tobacco by-products as a smoker in-
hales from four or five cigarettes.
Skasselatti-Sforzolini reported (Medical Tribune, Dec:4,
1967) that smoke from an idling cigarette contains almost
twice the tar and nicotine: of smoke inhaled while puffing.
on a cigarette. On the average, smoke inhaled while: puff-
ing on a cigarette contains 11.8 mg of tar and 0.8 mg of
nicotine, as compared to 22.1 mg of tar and 1.4 mg of nico-
tine frem idling smoke. Thus, smoke from an idling ciga-
rotte may be twice as toxic as smoke: inhaled by the
smoker. Although the concentration of harmful. sub-
stances inhaled by the nonsmoker is less than the concen-
tration inhaled by the smoker, the nonsmoker's exposure:
will be for a greater period of time. Scasselatti-Sforzolinii
indicated that smoking in an airplane "will obviously con-
stitute something of a menace to a nonsmoking passen-
ger:" It seems obvious that in the confines of an airplane,
where a nonsmoker may be required to sit next to one or
between two smokers, and where the alr circulation is typ-
ically poor, the nonsmoker will be subjected to a signifi-
cant health hazard from a smoker.
An editorial some years ago (Science 158:1527; 1967) con-
cerned the pollution of air by cigarette smoke. In a poorly
ventilated, smoke-filled room, concentrations of carbon
monoxide can easily reach several hundred parts per mil-
lion, thus exposing present smokers and nonsmokers to a
toxic hazard. Two other components of cigarette smoke
are nitrogen dioxide and hydrogen cyanide. The former is
an acutely irritating gas and occurs in cigarette smoke in
concentrations-liil times.that considered dangerous on ex-
tended exposure.
Questions and Answers
Cocarcinogenic Effect of Smoking and Asbestos
Exposure
Q
Inithe July 24, 1972, issue of THE JOURNAL a question appeared
about compensability for lung cancer developing in an as-
bestos worker who had'smoked a pack of cigarettes every day. for 30.
years: The consultant who answered the question said that' he did:
not Know of any such cases coming to litigation. He also stated he
was unaware of any firm conclusions having been derived from
studies aimed at determining whether or not there is a high inci.
dence of cancer in smokers exposed to asbestos. I have been under
the impression that asbestos workers who smoke are at a distinct
risk with respect to lung cancer, more so than asbestos workers who.
do not smoke. Can you tell me whether my, assumption is correct?
MD, Missouri
A
Information, concerning the increased risk of
lung cancer among asbestos workers has been pub-
lished." These data indicate that asbestos workers who
smoke cigarettes have approximately eight times the risk.
of death from lung cancer that other smokers of the same
age have, who do not work with asbestos.
E: C. Hammond, ScD, and I will shortly publish the re+
sults of another study bearing on this question. We have
followed up 9,590 asbestos-insulation workers from Jan 1,
1967, through Dec 31, 1971; each of these individuals had a
history of cigarette smoking. We have calculated expected
deaths and have compared them with those observed dur-
ing the period in question. While 25 deaths from lung can-
cer were expected, 134 occurred. There seems to be little
doubt, then, that exposure to asbestos significantly in-
creases the risk of lung cancer among cigarette smokers. I
am aware, too, of a number of cases, adjudicated in favor
of the plaintiff, that involved lung cancer associated with
asbestos exposure in cigarette-smoking asbestos workers.
tavgsc J. Seuskorr, MD
Mount Sinai Schuel of Medicine
New York

neoplasia. JAMA 204:106-112, 1968.
